title.narrative: WASH supplies for crisis-affected children and communities.

description.narrative:
Sudan has the lowest rate of access to improved sanitation in North Africa and the Middle East region. According to the MICS (2014), the percentage of the household population using both improved drinking water sources and improved sanitation facilities was only 28.2 per cent. Each year, the rainy season in Sudan causes flooding, which affect up to 13 million people, destroying or damaging homes and livelihoods. Floods also increase the risk of disease outbreaks, including acute watery diarrhea/cholera, particularly in areas where people have limited access to water and sanitation facilities and with limited health infrastructure.
As of 24 May 2020, the Federal Ministry of Health had recorded 3,628 cases of COVID-19 since the first confirmed case on 13 March 2020. The World Health Organization (WHO) has rated Sudan as an at risk country for the spread of COVID-19, based on risk profile and capacity of the country to respond to a potential outbreak. Sudan’s health system has limited capacity, marked by decades of limited investment, under-funding, and lack of qualified staff, infrastructure, equipment, medicines and supplies and has significant gaps in preparedness capacity for technical and operational implementation. Currently, the surveillance system does not cover the entire country and is structurally weak.
The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbates the humanitarian situation in Sudan already characterised by protracted, complex and overlapping humanitarian challenges. The situation of children and families in Sudan continues to deteriorate amid a continued severe and acute economic crisis, fueled by shortages of fuel, cash, and bread which has hit vulnerable children and families hard, and slowed down humanitarian and development operations including those of the government. According to the Humanitarian Needs Overview (2020), at the beginning of 2020, 9.3 million people – of which 5.3 million are children – are in need of humanitarian assistance (a sharp increase from the 5.5 million people/2.5 million children in need of humanitarian assistance in 2019). Sudan has one of the worst health indicators in the region and the disparity between urban and rural and between rich and poor is huge.
During emergencies it is essential to rapidly intervene to prevent a deterioration of the situation. Lifesaving supplies and services ensure that the immediate needs of the affected population are met, besides averting life-threatening situations, especially in situations of floods and disease outbreaks. Communication for Development (C4D) interventions are essential for ensuring immediate community awareness as well as long-term support in preparedness and prevention efforts that reduce the risk of future outbreaks. The proposed supplies will focus on lifesaving WASH interventions for the COVID-19 affected and at risk, AWD/cholera and flood-affected and at-risk children and their families in Gedaref, Kassala, North Darfur, North Kordofan, Red Sea, Sennar, South Darfur, South Kordofan, White Nile states through the purchase and distribution of lifesaving WASH supplies (water treatment chemicals, water storage tanks, soap, plastic sheets and slabs) and contribute the achievement of the allocation strategy and two outcomes of the 2020 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP): 1) Provide timely multi‐sectoral lifesaving assistance to crisis affected people to reduce mortality and morbidity, 2) Contribute to building resilience to recurrent shocks and improving vulnerable people’s access to basic services.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Multi-sectorial Health, WASH, and Protection emergency response to West Darfur's crisis

description.narrative: Intercommunal conflict and violence commenced on 15 January late evening in Krinding Camp, near El Geneina town and quickly spread across West Darfur. In the days following, there has been continued clashes within the town and attacks in villages across multiple localities, destroying thousands of homes and creating further displacement into El Geneina, neighbouring Krenik and Beida localities and into Chad. Intercommunal conflict has also extended into South Darfur, East Darfur and Central Darfur. With hundreds dead and injured, at least 97,000 people internally displaced within West Darfur. There are severe and immediate life-saving needs and protection risks to be addressed. SC has launched a multi-sectoral response to address the immediate life-threatening and protection needs of the displaced population, and to support transition to life-sustaining humanitarian intervention – focused on the health, WASH and protection sectors. There are critical shortages of medical staff and drugs whilst there is a massively increased caseload in El Geneina caused by the displacement. Infants’ vaccination schedules have been disrupted, as will be OTP service provision for those requiring nutrition intervention whilst the health risks are heightened, as displaced populations live in unsanitary and overcrowded conditions within spontaneous gathering sites, and with more limited access to food as families fled without their stocks and have competing needs to spend their money on. SC will support the MoH scale-up the delivery of quality primary healthcare services including dressing service, vaccinations for infants, OTP services, and reproductive health across multiple gathering points, through the establishment of mobile and static clinics at displacement locations secondment of staff provision of training and capacity-building support to healthcare workers (men and women) and direct provision of essential medicines, medical supplies, kits and equipment to men, women, girls and boys. SC will also strengthen referrals to secondary and more specialized health services, and engage in risk communication on the key health risks, including COVID-19. Water supply, although present at many gathering points within El Geneina, needs to be increased along with water storage capacity to cater for the daily minimum need of 7.5 litres per person per day. There are insufficient latrines and most of them need rehabilitating. The lack of proper and gender-segregated hygiene facilities represents a hazard in terms of protection against SGBV, and open defecation practices have been witnessed, which pose a real risk to water sources and the overall hygiene conditions of the population. SC will focus within this project on improving the hygiene and sanitation conditions at targeted gathering points through water trucking, Provision of water purifications, hygiene promotion and capacity building to community volunteers (men and women), and solid waste collection. Aside from the trauma associated with witnessing or experiencing violence and being suddenly displaced from homes, family separation and insecure shelter without privacy, plus a lack of material resources, exposes children and vulnerable adults to multiple forms of violence, abuse, exploitation, and neglect. These conditions also increase risks of SGBV to women and girls. SC will support the establishment and strengthening of community-based protection assistance networks, which will aim to mitigate the protection risks within their environments, raise awareness, and identify protection concerns. SC will undertake widespread protection monitoring across the gathering points, feeding back the key risks and concerns identified by communities, and will seek to strengthen referral pathways for Child Protection and SGBV. SC will PFA and MHPSS to identified high-need individuals.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: COVID response- Khartoum teaching Hospital Isolation Centre

description.narrative: In 2020 and early 2021, SCI has through SHF funding supported the Khartoum teaching hospital isolation center with rehabilitation, medical equipment, furniture, infection prevention and control (IPC) supplies including PPEs and staff DSA. With this support, the ITC becomes fully functional with increased ICU capacity and can provide other urgent care including 24/7 dialysis care. The Ministry of Health allocates required staff, protocols and played the leading role in the Isolation center's management. More than 223 staff in different departments supported the intervention and were paid DSA. 185 IC regular staff and 6 program managers supported the intervention while the others were on call bases and not part of the routine service provided at the center eg. Neurosurgery, urology, orthopedic, ENT, as the patients care is usually in form of a holistic approach. SCI maintained a supervisory role and provided technical support to ensure quality health services delivery. Currently, the number of severe and critical cases alarmingly increasing every day, which indicates the third wave of COVID19 in Sudan. According to the Isolation center command (ICC), up to 45 critical patients are on the waiting list searching for ICU beds in Khartoum, which is unprecedented. Currently, there are 49 patients admitted in the ITC including 24 in ICU and 25 patients are all oxygen-dependent. The number of cases at the center may exceed 100 because of the increased number of infections and also the 13 days of average length stay. The situation illustrates the urgency and the importance of sustaining the isolation center through the 3rd wave of the COVID19. With SHF support, SCI proposing to continue supporting the ITC with the necessary IPC supplies including PPEs, consumables, and staff DSA in addition to the provision of technical oversite. The requested SHF funding will be used to procure essential medicines, IPC supplies, and consumables, PPE for isolation center workers, provision of staff DSA and Lab supplies.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Institutional Feeding Support to in Quarantine Centres

description.narrative: Under the COVID-19 UN response, WFP shall provide support to Government of Syria quarantine centres, via institutional feeding and will cover a maximum of 29,000 people. Support will be provided either through a WFP contracted wholesaler arrangement or through the provision of ready to eat rations.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting the COVID19 response in Rural Damascus Governorate.

description.narrative: This six-month intervention builds on INTERSOS’s existing geographical and sectors specific experience inside Syria and aims to prevent and response to the COVID 19 outbreak for a 37972 conflict affected people including IDPs, returnees and vulnerable host communities in Rural Damascus Governorate. The proposed intervention is supporting the national health and protection response and the identified most critical actions in order to enhance the national capacity and mitigate the consequences of COVID 19. In line with priorities of the existing UNCT Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan – and as summarized in the COVID-19 Global Humanitarian Response Plan launched on 25th of March 2020, the intervention responds to the health needs for a) infection prevention and control thought procurement and distribution of PPEs and medical supplies to three SARC health facilities, training on IPC for 100 HWs, CHWs for the targeted HFs, monitor the implementation of IPC plans in the designated healthcare facilities b) case management through provision of medical support equipment for three SARC facilities and provision of MHPSS for 50 health workers ,15 community mobilizers and 15 volunteers c) risk communication and community engagement – designing and developing appropriate IEC materials for awareness campaigns, using accepted broadcast/print/social-traditional media, and social mobilization through community mobilizers d) enhance the community surveillance through the creation and promotion of community sentinels’ mechanisms in the a areas of intervention. The action is in line with the Protection response plan for COVID 19 through the distribution of dignity kits for vulnerable women and girls, promoting protection awareness session for CP, GBV inside the targeted communities, reinforcing the mechanisms for identification and referrals of vulnerable cases thought community approach and the provision of PSS/PFA for the affected persons. The services will be provided at community level through community mobilizers and SARC volunteers trained and supervised by INTERSOS protection staff. The capacity building and awareness activities modalities proposed in the intervention are adapted to the COVID 19 context: ToT training, on – line interactive sessions, small groups of attendees/participants will ensure physical distancing and avoid the spread of the infection. The intervention has been defined in coordination with SARC relevant departments, Health and Protection sector, in coordination with health and protection partners operating in the same areas of intervention and will ensure safe and dignity access to health and protection services.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency support for COVID-19 affected vulnerable communities in Aleppo Governorate through risk communication, community engagement and specialized protection services.

description.narrative: The project proposal addresses the protection needs of the most vulnerable IDPs, returnees and host communities exposed to COVID-19 risk of infection, through different sets of activities to be implemented in Jabel Saman, As-Safira, Zerbeh and Abu Tuhul sub-districts. It is based on COOPI previous and ongoing implementation of community-based protection programs in Aleppo, Rural Damascus and Dara’a Governorates. Individual assistance for the most vulnerable women and girls will be provided through the distribution of dignity kits, both in remote and unserved urban areas. The identification of women benefiting from dignity kits will be done in collaboration and through the engagement of women committees’ members, supported by COOPI protection staff. Dignity kits will also be provided to women sheltered in quarantine/isolation facilities as currently SARC only has access, beneficiaries list will be handled by SARC and distribution will be done through SARC personnel. To promote risk communication and community engagement (RCCE), the use of remote communication channels will be prioritized to provide culturally appropriate and targeted awareness messages and information related to COVID-19. Community-based communication will be pursued mainly engaging volunteers, committees and stakeholders, as preferential sources of risk information dissemination about COVID-19, in the set-up of the risk information campaign. Acknowledging risk perceptions, behaviors, existing barriers and specific needs, COOPI will target communities/groups with accurate and tailored information, spread through the appropriate communication channels. Depending on the network coverage and beneficiaries’ access to media, radio, phone, social media will be used alternatively. Through regular and proactive communication, COOPI will contribute to reduce social stigma about COVID-19, by providing accurate information, to improve dialogue and avoid misunderstandings. In collaboration with community members and in line with WHO and Protection sector guidelines, relevant IEC materials will be developed to be context specific and immediately applicable. Children will be targeted with specific awareness materials and parents will be previously trained to support children in understanding the basic prevention measures on COVID-19 and overcome psychological distress. Community-based protection will be carried out through volunteers, mobilizers and committees. Based on the experience gained during the implementation of protection interventions in Nashabiyeh and Aleppo, Women, Elderly and Child Welfare Committees will be established ant trained to identify and monitor the increasing of protection risk related to COVID-19 pandemic, to facilitate the access of the most vulnerable to remote case management services and to raise awareness on protection (PSS, CP, SGBV, mine risk education). Support activities will be carried out to ensure continuation of critical protection activities, such as remote case management, counseling and psychological first aid (PFA). COOPI will engage with key actors in the area, to ensure a set up/strengthening and constant update of the referral pathways, ensuring that PoCs have access to accurate and relevant information to access the services needed. PWSN requiring physical, hearing, speech therapy will receive specialized assistance through video sessions prerecorded by therapists. Caregivers will be remotely trained from specialized staff and some tablet per targeted area will be distributed with the support of volunteers to be used on a rotational basis by the people assisted. To further enhance social cohesion, COOPI will sustain the development of a community self-support groups. Volunteers trained on COVID-19 prevention measures and provided with PPA, will be in charge to assist the most vulnerable, as elderly, PWSN, women headed HHs, to carry out daily activities, reduce the family burden and facilitate the supply of basic items.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: COVID-19 Pandemic Response for Extremely Vulnerable in Need Today (PREVINT)

description.narrative:
COVID-19 Pandemic Response for Extremely Vulnerable in Need Today (PREVINT) is a 6-month life-sustaining principled humanitarian response. Informed by first-hand studies and rapid needs analyses, the response addresses urgent humanitarian needs in the context of COVID-19 with the principle objective of: Local schemes and systems capacitated to minimize impact of COVID-19 on vulnerable and at-risk populations across Hama Governorate. To achieve this objective the response works towards two inter-related outcomes:
Outcome 1: Enhanced capacity of health facilities in Hama Governorate to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. Under this outcome the Hama Central Laboratory and Salamieh National Hospital are equipped with COVID-19 medical equipment and supplies. 250 COVID-19 testing kits and one PCR device will be procured for Hama Central Laboratory and three ventilators will be procured for Salamieh National Hospital. Health specialists and technicians from each hospital will be trained by the WHO and MoH to properly use the acquired equipment as relevant to their work.
Outcome 2: Increased capacity of target health workers to provide safe health services in the context of COVID-19. Under this outcome, 1,920 health workers from both Salamieh National Hospital and Hama National Hospital will be equipped with PPE and trained on effective use as per WHO and MoH guidelines.
Through these health interventions, the response will directly reach 182,163 people across Salamieh, Hama, As-Suqaylabiyah, Masyaf, and Muhradah Districts of Hama Governorate.
As much as possible, interventions have been coordinated with the UN Health Cluster, the WHO, and the Ministry of Health at the national and provincial level and align with the SHF Allocation Paper and AKDN’s Global and in-country response.

job-title.narrative: Senior Donor and Grants Coordination Officer

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency WASH assistance for vulnerable households and communities to prevent and mitigate COVID-19 transmission

description.narrative:
After more than nine years of conflict across the country, Syria is particularly vulnerable to a large-scale COVID-19 outbreak. This project will provide life-saving WASH support to people vulnerable to COVID-19 transmission in Aleppo, Hama, Idleb and Rural Damascus in coordination with other actors. DRC will flexibly intervene where most needed, including where DRC is strategically positioned for access in comparison to other responders. DRC is already working in Aleppo, Hama, and Rural Damascus governorates and will use this action to scale-up assistance, ensuring a comprehensive response to the population in need, including the 7,750 beneficiaries targeted under this action. Coordination with other actors will maximize response efficiency. With access to Aleppo, Hama and Rural Damascus facilitated through SARC and relevant technical line ministries, DRC stands ready to begin activities for this project as soon as it is funded. DRC is coordinating with SARC and local authorities to gain access to Idleb and have received positive feedback that this will be facilitated in a timely manner.
The immediate basic needs on the ground for affected populations, as reported through the WASH sector include access to safe and sufficient water and hygiene items to practice proper hygiene practices in order to help prevent human-to-human transmission. The targeted beneficiary populations are living in communities with little or no existing WASH infrastructure in place. Hygiene kits, water, and water tanks will be distributed in target locations to slow, suppress and stop the spread of COVID-19.
The project accords with the WASH sector’s COVID-19 strategy of providing assistance to ensure good and consistently applied WASH practices in communities. It will together with the interventions of other actors create a safe environment for other humanitarian activities in the sectors of education, protection, and livelihoods to be delivered. Project locations will remain flexible to enable DRC to respond to the most critical needs expected locations are vulnerable communities within Aleppo, Hama, Idleb and Rural Damascus, however DRC maintains the flexibility to prioritize activities in certain locations based on need meaning not all activities will necessarily be implemented in all selected locations.
In order to reduce, mitigate and address COVID-19 risk factors, DRC proposes a comprehensive WASH program which will work to expand access to vital water and hygiene assistance to highly vulnerable and underserved populations that are particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 transmission. Interventions will include hygiene kit distribution in communities and water trucking including water tank provision when needed.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integrated individual protection response in Damascus and Rural Damascus for the most vulnerable population groups during the Covid-19 crisis.

description.narrative: With the present proposal AVSI aims at improving the protection of the most vulnerable people during the Covid-19 crisis through integrated individual support and community protection monitoring. The action targets 1517 individuals: IDPs, returnees, elderly, women head of households, disable persons and persons with chronic diseases in the area of Damascus (especially Dwela area), Jaramana and East Ghouta. The project, in collaboration with SARC, plans to provide cash assistance for protection purposes to targeted beneficiaries (1230), dignity kits for vulnerable girls and women IDPs (159 women + 22 girls: they will receive both cash assistance and dignity kits) or returnees women head of households in East Ghouta (287, they will receive only dignity kits). Furthermore, the initiative will implement Covid-19 awareness, protection monitoring and follow-up of assistance, with possible services referrals by SARC, through individual sample household visits (we expect to visit 20% of beneficiaries, i.e. 300 HH).

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Sanitization for Covid-19 Reaching Underserved Beneficiaries (SCRUB)

description.narrative: The Sanitization for Covid-19 Reaching Underserved Beneficiaries (SCRUB) Project will provide target 90,000 individuals (including 25,200 men, 25,200 women, 19,800 boys and 19,800 girls with WASH assistance in Homs and Rural Damascus to reduce the spread of COVID-19 in Syria. ADRA will provide monthly supplies of hygiene kits to 10,000 families (50,000 individuals) who are part of ADRA’s food voucher program funded by USAID (Food For Peace) for three months. ADRA will also rehabilitate the WASH facilities in four health facilities in the target areas for hygiene kit distribution, increasing community resilience, with an estimated 40,000 beneficiaries.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancement of coping mechanisms and reducing of protection risks for PWDs, WMBG during COVID-19, through increasing awareness and providing CASH assistance, PSS, and remote PFA services, (Protection)

description.narrative:
This intervention is inserted in the framework of strategic objectives 1, 2, and 3 of the HRP COVID-19 2020, and it is aligned with the protection sector objectives and priorities which is designed to complement the efforts of the Protection sector during COVID-19. This project aims to increase resiliency and improve coping mechanisms for vulnerable groups particularly women, children, and PWDs, During COVID-19 through the distribution of Recreational and Hygiene kits for children, Cash for protection, and remote GBV case management.
The project targets both host communities, already existing IDPs and returnees in need of support in Aleppo, and Rural Damascus, for a total amount of 6000 direct beneficiaries including 2,240 PWDs.
This intervention will be implemented in partnership with the Syrian Commission for Family Affairs and Population (SCFPA), since TDH already have two Centers operating Rural Damascus( Jaramah) and Aleppo, implemented with SCPFA, that provide service to PWDs, including physical rehabilitation, therefore, we have a huge number of PWDs beneficiaries, and in this allocation, TDH is aiming to enhance the services in these locations based already conducted need assessments, and the already available beneficiaries list including more than 3000 PWDs.
The project will be implemented in two phases: 1- The first phase: of the project will focus on rapidly preparing and build capacity for staff and volunteers to operate safely and effectively to deliver the project activities, including online training on Hygiene promotion, COVDID-19 preventive procedures, Remote PFA, and PSS during COVID-19 1- The Second phase: after the staff and volunteers have been trained and prepared, the project activities will start and will be focused on delivering the services in safe and effective methods, to the most vulnerable groups, and will ensure that 40% of beneficiaries in all activities, are People with Diasblies form the TDH/SCPFA rehabilitation centers’ Database, and will provide the following activities: a- customized children Recreational and hygiene kits for 2000 children - in addition to a Brief Hygiene promotion session during hygiene kit distribution, b- Psychosocial support for COVIDfor 1000 beneficiaries, in addition to complementary cash assistance to improve the coping capacity of the most vulnerable groups such as refugees, elderly, people with chronic diseases, women head of households the target will be form preselected beneficiaries based on previous need assessment will be mainly of women Headed houses, and 40% PWDs of the total, in two locations (Hanano, Jarmanah), and are facing immediate protection risk due to COVID-19 such as being evicted from their rented homes, c- And lastly, the project will carry out an awareness campaign using remote modality, by creating multiple social groups (WhatsApp/ telegram) for 3000 beneficiaries (1500 in each of the two locations), the remote awareness will cover topics on Hygiene promotion, COVID-19, and domestic violence.

participating-org.narrative: The Syrian Commission for Family and Population Affairs

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response WASH Interventions for Vulnerable Communities in Rural Damascus

description.narrative: COVID-19 is having an unprecedented impact on all countries. Syria with its existing humanitarian crisis is particularly at risk and less equipped to respond and protect vulnerable populations. Strong emphasis has been placed on preparedness and response actions which support the containment of the COVID-19 outbreak in Syria as well a focus on the most vulnerable populations. More so, WASH interventions have been identified as constituting a key pillar in COVID-19 infection prevention and control. It is behind this backdrop that ZOA is proposing to provide necessary WASH services, supplies and consumables to vulnerable communities to decrease risks and prevent the spread of COVID-19. ZOA is targeting two IDP compounds in Babella, Rural Damascus with WASH Sector aligned activities- distribution of hygiene kits, solid waste management interventions and distribution of awareness raising materials and risk communication. The WASH needs for the target locations were identified in the WASH Sector HNO 2020 assessment. Project activities are planned for 4 months and targeted at 20,000 direct beneficiaries with priority given to the most vulnerable households.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting preparedness, mitigation and response to COVID-19 on the most vulnerable populations in Syria

description.narrative: COVID-19 is exacerbating the already dire humanitarian situation in Syria, particularly for the most vulnerable, already suffering from multiple-impacts of 9 years conflict, leaving the most vulnerable (women, children, elderly, persons with disabilities) without access to healthcare, food, safe water, sanitation and stretching the already limited infrastructure. The rapid spread of COVID-19, coupled with a public health system that is fractured from years of conflict, creates additional challenges for the operational response. Maintaining access to hygiene is crucial to support a healthy immune system and reduce the spread of the COVID-19 virus. Taking into consideration the UNOCHA 2020 COVID-19 Reserve Allocation and the needs identified in the field, AAH will focus on preventing the spread of COVID-19 by providing life-saving assistance: hygiene kits and awareness posters teaching communities prevention, early detection and control of COVID-19. The project will address the immediate needs of vulnerable and crisis-affected populations in Aleppo governorate by distributing 4,500 hygiene kits to 22,500 individuals. The content of the hygiene kits is in line with the WASH cluster’s specifications. The following communities of two sub-districts (Menbij and Jebel Saman) in Aleppo governorate will be targeted, based on initial Rapid Needs Assessments and stakeholder input: Shahda, Wadihah Al-Jadidah, Sukkariyeh, Kharayej Deham, Khan Al-Asal, Salheen, and As-Sukkari. The dissemination and hanging of awareness posters in public places will be conducted by SARC, and the distribution of hygiene kits will be done by the local NGO DARB Association, which has access in the target communities. Action Against Hunger received the approval from the Ministry of Social Affairs and Labor and from SARC to work with the local NGO. After the necessary due diligence, AAH signed an MOU with DARB Association. The proposed project mainstreams and incorporates protection principles and promotes meaningful access, safety and dignity. AAH is capitalizing on lessons learnt and best practices from previous interventions and considers Sphere Standards, relevant Clusters’ guidance and WHO’s recommendations on COVID 19. Particular attention has been paid to ensure activities implemented by AAH are not duplicating activities undertaken by other aid agencies in the area but complement activities in the field.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Improving COVID 19 preparedness and prevention through integrated WASH interventions in Rural Damascus

description.narrative: Oxfam is proposing a six-month rapid public health response to reach 32,500 people affected by the crisis in Rural Damascus Governorates. In addition to this, approximately 500,000 individuals will be reached by hygiene promotion messages through a media campaign in the whole country. The proposed action aims to improve the affected communities' access to information on awareness in order to improve the prevention of COVID19 risks, and maintain key health and hygiene practices in the communities . A media campaign will be complimented by family hygiene kit distributions, cash for work activities relating to sterilizing high touch areas and message dissemination in the community, and improving access to solid waste management services. The project is aligned to the WASH Sector strategy for COVID Response it is a well defined response strategy suitable to the restricted movement situation and the existing security challenges (direct implementation through a competent media company, reliable and experienced volunteers and focal points). Oxfam will collaborate with relevant ministries, governorates amp directorates, the WASH sub-sectors and NGOs.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Support preparedness and response to COVID19 in Syria

description.narrative: The project aims at supporting preparedness and response to COVID19 in Syria, especially in Damascus and Rural Damascus, Activities will include: - Procure medical supplies and PPEs to support Altamayoz’s health workers at Almidan center and harasta for 5months as a continuation of work beyond June 2020. and to support another center for AlTamayoz in Rural Damascus and 7 NGOs who provide health services and lack the needed support to maintain safe environment while providing service during COVID-19 . 5 out of those centers are in Rural Damascus and 5 are in Damascus. health workers, and awareness raising facilitators will also be provided with PPEs, the total number of those who will be provided with PPEs is 400 person The facilities that will be supported with disinfectants are the those of the 7 NGOs in addition to 3 facilities for AlTamayoz which provide health services. This activity will be according to pillar No. 6 of health sector response plan which is infection prevention and control. - Awareness raising on protection issues (GBV and CP) and on health issues (prevention of COVID-19) through outreach Volunteers as well as at AlTamayoz centers in Damascus and Rural Damascus (Harasta and Saqbq). Awareness will be done by using remote methods (Whats App groups, SMS, Facebook,.), or by one person to one person approach, it will also target pregnant and lactating women. During this activity, women who are observed to have protection risks will be provided with dignity kits and pregnant and lactating women kits. awareness raising providers of one to one will follow prevention measures and will be supported with PPEs. Volunteers will receive trainings on COVID19 awareness - Provide cash assistance to the most vulnerable population to alleviate negative socio-economic impacts of COVID-19 on them. the exact outcome of cash distribution is to support women who are most at risk of GBV and exploitation (women households, GBV survivors, the victim of early marriage or domestic violence, or have family member with disabilities or elderly, or she or her children has critical or chronic disease) and protect them from exploitation and abuse and reduce the amplification of violence risks they are exposed to due to the current situation. Most women who are the households and not able to work during the current curfew are exposed to domestic violence, and many of them are at risk of engaging in harmful coping mechanism, this was observed during our remote contact with women who were approaching women and girls’ safe spaces (WGSS) supported by UNFPA. Cash money distribution follows the following steps: 1-choose the most vulnerable families according to vulnerability criteria (Women headed households, GBV survivor, families with one or more persons with disability or specific needs, women who or her children have health or psychological problems (domestic violence,..), families who have one or more elderly persons, girls households (early marriage)) 2-A printed list will be prepared for the chosen families, it will contain the name, and the amount each family will receive in addition to a special space for fingerprint to prove money receive. Another validation method is an electronic fingerprint. 3- the fixed amount of money is prepared in the financial department and under supervision of the treasurer and the financial manager, each amount is put in a closed envelop. The financial process is also well organized and under control of internal policies 4- cash distribution will be done in AlTamayoz center, and could be done in Women and girls safe spaces supported by UNFPA in AlMidan,Dummar and Harasta to support 200 women with the amount equal to 75 $ per month. the distribution will be done along with maintaining the physical distance between beneficiaries. 5- In case the women couldn't reach any of AlTamayoz facilitoes, then AlTamayoz will manage to do distribution via mobile team with maintaining the needed documentation

title.narrative: Awareness raising about COVID-19 with NFI distribution for vulnerable families at Homs Governorate

description.narrative: the project aims to reduce the risk of an outbreak of Covid-19 virus , and aid the precautionary measures of the Syrian Government to suppress and slow the transaction of the virus through quick and effective intervention in WASH sector, the scope of work will include 3 rural areas of Homs city (Hassyeh - Masskaneh - Baba Amr) in addition to some neighborhood in the city it self. the initial target of beneficiaries from all activities will round up to 8250 person of the most vulnerable population with emphasis on Women-Headed families and IDPs , the project will cover the need of those beneficiaries starting from providing them with essential hygiene items , fixing the sanitation facilities and preform a daily sterilization to a 12 shelters located in the areas of intervention , and ending with conducting a safe and informative awareness sessions (whether group sessions or individual sessions) those activities will result a more protected communities in the rural areas , and more prepared shelter centers to face the global pandemic of Covid-19

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: To limit human-to-human transmission of COVID-19 among vulnerable populations in Syria through prevention and response activities in the targeted areas.

description.narrative: Contain the spread of the Corona pandemic and provide a comprehensive response to people from the risk of the Corona pandemic, especially the most vulnerable (community, IDPs, returnees, the elderly, persons with disabilities, children at risk of malnutrition, people with chronic diseases, care homes (juveniles). Etc., by providing specialized services to respond to this pandemic, reducing the deterioration of the social situation and livelihoods, enabling teams and work cadres, and equipping health centers and dispensaries with the necessary medical equipment and tools. These activities will be implemented in the following governorates: Damascus countryside, Hama, Aleppo, and Idlib. The overall number of beneficiaries reached /11515/ (direct persons) and /15000/ (indirect persons). All these areas are with high severity scale from (4 to 6) according to the sector information Expected outputs of program implementation: 1- Provide Dignity Kits To the most vulnerable groups such as returnees, elderly, people with chronic diseases, women heads of households, people with specific needs, and women survived of violence. 2- Provide Case Management for vulnerable and most vulnerable people (GBV, CM, PSS) to the aforementioned areas. 3- Provide community-led initiatives There could be initiatives on other topics, depending on the study of needs and available resources in each region. Note that the SSSD will implement all the proposed activities in areas where SSSD does not have other partners: such as UNHCR This enables us to cover a wider area

description.narrative: the first section - Community-based communication and support: Will be strengthen protection hotlines and use social media to continue the critical protection activities and first aid, case management and strengthening referral pathways provide awareness and information on protection issues related to COVID 19 As follows : 1- children and caregivers will be reached Monthly targeting of categories: Men( 1334 )Women( 1500) Boys( 1834 )Girls( 1334 ) The total during 6 months becomes (36000) thousand by placing , and benefiting from social networking sites to provide service during the ban period and after the ban is ended we will have a sufficient period, 2- An animation video about awareness and psychosocial support will be created and audio messages will be created provide awareness and information on protection issues related to COVID 19 .Where the designs will be shared before proceeding with you. 3- There will be some "awareness-raising, targeted sessions" that do not exceed 10 children, mothers or men, while adhering to the terms of separation. title.narrative: Equipping and Rehabilitation 2nd floor of Al-Birr Hospital as an Isolation center for affected by COVID-19

description.narrative:
During the current response of COVID-19, AL-Birr played its role in the national efforts of fighting COVID-19 and managed to rehabilitate the 8th floor of its building and convert it to an isolation center with a capacity of 24 beds for isolation and treatment and 20 bed-ICU for the treatment of severe cases where continuous supply of oxygen is needed. All of it are equipped with monitors and ventilators. Also Al-Birr managed to convert the out-patient clinics department to quarantine center with a capacity of 27 beds. The quarentine and isolation centers have seperated enterances. All of this was with support of local donors who trusts Al-Birr since the association have a good reputation and earned the society trust through its humanitarian work since 1956. The Hospital now is one of the approved centers by the directorate of health in Homs for the treatment of affected people by COVID-19 (DoH letter is attached).
In order to be more prepared and ready in case of any outbreak of the pandemic, and since Homs city has no enough public hospitals nor enough intensive care units and beds, Al-Birr project aims to increase the capacity of Al-Birr isolation center for COVID-19 and of Homs governorate in general in order to save lives of people might be affected by the virus. Therefore, the project will complete the rehabilitation process of ICU department (which was the largest ICU in Homs during the last decade) in the second floor of the hospital building, and convert it to an isolation center. The rehabilitation needed for the 2nd floor is only minor rehabilitation work such as some carpentry and aluminum work, installing doors and windows, light plumping and electrical work. The rehabilitation could be achieved in a month at the latest, Al-Birr has enough equipment for this floor, the project will help to purchase and equip the isolation center with needed devices (beds and its accessories) to be added to the available devices. After rehabilitation, the capacity of Al-Birr hospital ICU will be 30 beds in addition to its current 20 ICU beds. So, Al-Birr will be able to provide treatment for 60 patients monthly (300 patients in 5 months)
ِAccording to Chinese reports, CT plays “a vital role in early detection, observation, and disease evaluation.”. While RT-PCR sensitivity do not exceed 70%, CT-scan will ensure rapid improved quarantining, and tailored public health measures. Al-Birr Hospital has one of the best and developed multi-slice computed tomography scan devices in Syria that has the ability to do 128-slides scans. This device could significantly contribute in the efforts of detecting the affected cases by COVID-19 but it needs maintenance (replacing its x ray tube) that could be conducted in 1-2 months and and the project aims to rehabilitate it and put it in work to support the detection, observation and evaluating diseases of affected people where 600 patients may benefit of these scans

title.narrative: Provision of health services and assistance to isolation centers in Al Hol camp and Al Areesha camp in Hassakeh province.

description.narrative: The camps are more vulnerable to the transmission of COVED-19 due to the overcrowding of the displaced people in the camps and lack of protective supplies and tools and shortage of the curative health services. So that, the need to provision of the curative services to the residents of the camp is the priority, thus WHO established isolation centers in Al Hol, Al Areesha camps, to provide curative services for the infected moderate cases of COVID-19 where the other potential acute levels of COVID-19 will be referred out the camps for advanced level of treatment at Damascus level. the project will contribute to provide the necessary requirements of medical, protective supplies and medicines as well the logistical services and well provision of the medical staff that needed to facilitate the provision of the treatment for the potential infected cases at the isolation centers in the camps. the curative services provided at the isolation centers will be linked with the other health partners in close coordination with WHO. - As of the date of the field assessment, Al Hol camp, direct beneficiaries, reads 18,100 families of 65,705 persons of which 6,940 of displaced families of 25,125 persons and 2,851 foreigner women headed of families (migrants) and 8,304 Iraqi refugee families of 30,735 persons. where Al Areesha camp holds 2,500 displaced families of 15,000 people. As a total in both camps, the direct beneficiaries reads 20,600 families of displaced and refugee families of 80,705 people.

title.narrative: SARC’s integrated response to save lives and minimise the overall impacts of COVID-19 related morbidity and mortality through the provision of timely health and WASH services to the most vulnerable communities in Syria.

description.narrative: SARC has developed a COVID Response Plan and has already started specific COVID-19 preparedness work, in particular with a mass sterilization campaign of the streets and public areas of Damascus, Al-Hassakeh, Aleppo, Homs, Deir-Ez-Zour and Daraa as well as a mass awareness raising campaigns using existing bill boards and community-based first aid (CBHFA) programme. The SARC COVID response plan focuses on preparedness, containment, mitigation and early recovery using SARC’s existing programmes that have been implemented throughout the Syrian conflict such as providing medical and food assistance to those most in need. Under the plan SARC has put in place measures to ensure the continuity of essential health care and WASH services targeting the most vulnerable populations including communities affected by the COVID-19 pandemic as part of the SARC business continuity plan. The plan prioritizes increased protection of SARC volunteers who put their health and lives at risk in the course of delivering services to affected people. The proposed response is to reduce community transmission, morbidity and mortality associated with the COVID-19 pandemic and increase human dignity to affected communities in Syria through an integrated and gender-responsive approach focusing on health, WASH and psychosocial support and building on the already established SARC partnerships between SARC and RCRC Movement Partners, UN agencies and the international non-governmental organizations. The response is very much in line with the priorities identified in SARC’s COVID Response Plan and the technical clusters in Syria, the strategic priorities of SARC and global COVID response strategies. For this project SARC will target communities who are most vulnerable to COVID infection and first responders particularly in those governorates where the MoH has identified positive cases and those communities in IDPs camps and collective shelters in Aleppo, Al-Hasakah, Hama, Homs, Deraa, Damascus and Rural Damascus. Specifically, and to ensure a rapid, efficient, and coordinated response by the SARC health teams, key activities in the proposed action will focus on the following: Provision and distribution of personal protective equipment (PPE) to SARC volunteers and staff providing services in SARC health facilities comprising of Primary Health Clinics (PHC), Mobile Health Units (MHU), Emergency Health Points (EHP), Mobile Medical Teams (MMT), First Aid Centers and Ambulance Services. Community hygiene promotion activities as part of a broader risk communication and community engagement strategy. Provision of hygiene kits to affected populations in all the seven targeted governorates of Syria. The above will be complemented by SARC’s ongoing activities including training of SARC health and WASH volunteers and staff on epidemic control to ensure they are better prepared to respond to health in emergencies and epidemic control. Through these activities the project aims to achieve the following: Increase the capacity of 1,950 SARC health volunteers and staff to provide high quality preventative and promotive health services in SARC health facilities Enhance the capacity of SARC’s 126 health facilities comprising of emergency health points (EHPs), clinics, mobile health units (MHUs), medical teams (MMTs), first aid centers and ambulances to deliver and track health services with a focus on COVID-19 Increase the practice of hand-hygiene and hand washing among vulnerable communities targeting 222,500 beneficiaries Increase access to hygiene kits targeting 37,500 beneficiaries

title.narrative: Child Protection prevention and response to COVID19 pandemic in Syria

description.narrative:
Project Summary : The project will be implemented in all governorates in Syria Al hol camp) through three implementing partners (Al Mawada, SARC, Nour Foundation amp GOPA) focusing on provision of i). Community-based communication and support: The project shall ensure dissemination accurate information on prevention of contracting COVID19 pandemic and mitigation of its negative impacts on children and families implemented as an integrated approach into other child protection response including prevention of violence against children and women including GBV , PSEA and Risk Education for IDPS, refugees and host communities as specified in different locations. The information shall be disseminated to 190,600 people through use remote/ online such as social media, phones, Facebook, toll free hotlines. UNICEF and partners shall also continue to provide the critical child protection activities including Psychological first aid, psychosocial support, case management and strengthening referral pathways for access to specialized health services for addressing COVID19. MHPSS interventions shall promote the wellbeing of caregivers so they can provide children with a sense of safety, stability and normalcy, helping to restore or maintain the developmental process.
ii).Protection community-based activities: The project will ensure increased in the number of trained and skilled community outreach volunteers and mobilizers (2000): Work in collaboration with community volunteers registered by MoSAL in collaboration with WHO and UNFPA in respective districts to identify child protection and humanitarian need, support the most vulnerable within their communities, conduct awareness raise on prevention of violence against women and children including GBV and PSEA for women, girls, men and boys. The community volunteers shall also facilitate access to specialized services through case management by identifying and referring cases for urgent protection assistance/ support. Additionally, to ensure that other vulnerable groups such as persons with disabilities, pregnant women, elderly and persons suspected or confirmed to have contracted COVID-19 are provided accurate information and referred to services. Ensure that vulnerable people including those in self /institution quarantine and isolation access MHPSS services interventions which will promote the wellbeing of caregivers so they can provide children with a sense of safety, stability and normalcy, helping to restore or maintain the developmental process. And provide accurate information on referrals to specialized services /treatment at health facilities. The community facilitators shall mainly use remote services approach, adhering to social and physical distancing measures in provision of assistance to communities. Case management for vulnerable 500 children (250 boys amp 250girls) which are ongoing or new cases shall be continued, since some of the restrictive measures to respond to COVID19 pandemic may have dire negative consequences on children and families, some family may be separated or children become unaccompanied, these must be prevented, however, whenever it occurs, there must be a mechanism of preventing family separation but also providing viable alternative care arrangement which addresses the needs and best interest of the children to maintain family unity and address violence, abuse and exploitation which may occur amidst the COVID19 pandemic response. There will be integration of gender-based violence prevention and awareness raising information campaigns and information on referral services including reproductive health services already in IDP or refugees Camps, collective shelters or communities, safe spaces for women and girls in collaboration with UNHCR and UNFPA in the camp level. This would facilitate reducing the risk of Gender based violence and other forms of violence against most vulnerable categories especially in IDP camps.

title.narrative: Enhance women protection and dignity and maintain the provision of maternal health and other sexual and reproductive health and GBV services during COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative: In January 2020, WHO announced Corona virus disease (COVID-19) as an infectious disease caused by a newly discovered corona virus Since then, there has been an increase of mild, severe and fatal COVID-19 cases around the world with the risk of severe disease associated with COVID-19 all over the world currently considered moderate for the general population and very high for populations with defined risk factors associated with elevated risk.During public health emergencies, human and financial resources are often diverted from various health programs to respond to the infectious disease outbreak. Sexual and reproductive health services are being impacted by the pandemic and must be prioritized in this action UNFPA in coordination with UN sister agencies and national authorities will maintain continuity of reproductive health and maternal health services in line with health cluster response plan, national response plan and UNFPA preparedness and response plan to ensure safe pregnancy and childbirth in addition, to protect health workers in primary, secondary and tertiary level of services, UNFPA will provide needed life saving equipment and supplies to maternal health facilities in 11 governorates and personal protection equipment and sanitizers to all reproductive health services points of Ministry Of Health (MOH) not included among the facilities covered by WHO. This coordinated intervention will ensure continuity of regular SRH services provision and activities, also through other donor support, in all Syrian governorates and in the most vulnerable locations.Since the first case of COVID-19 was reported in Syria on March 23rd, the Government of Syria has introduced measures amid fears of a spike of the novel corona virus. These measures include movement restrictions between governorates, between city centers and rural areas, as well as a countrywide curfew in effort to ensure social distancing and self-isolation to minimize the risks of infections. Part of these efforts also includes a ban on public gatherings and activities that involve large numbers of people. In Syria, people affected by humanitarian crises, particularly those displaced and/or living in camps and camp-like settings, are faced with challenges accessing health services that were otherwise available before the COVID-19 outbreak. Several measures have been taken at international and national levels to contain the spread of the virus, which has disrupted people's normal lives including humanitarian response, in addition to the already existing dire humanitarian needs before the pandemic. In conforming to these measures, UNFPA is adapting new programming modalities to ensure continuation of safe delivery of life saving GBV interventions while at the same time putting strict measures in place to ensure the safety of staff and beneficiaries. With this funding request, UNFPA is seeking to provide dignity kits to vulnerable women and girls (pregnant and lactating women, women living with disabilities and female heads of household) in Dar’a governorate through an e-voucher system in partnership with WFP. In addition, UNFPA also seeks to enhance access to timely and safe GBV life saving services by establishing a confidential electronic referral system and providing information on GBV risks, women and girls safety and COVID-19 through online platforms. At the same time, UNFPA will leverage on a network of community volunteers established by MOSAL who will be trained on basic communication skills with GBV survivors and mentored on a regular basis to improve their capacity in the provision of Psychological First Aid and timely referrals to those in need of care and support. UNFPA will also develop and disseminate a safety audit checklist for quarantine and isolation facilities and provide GBV risk mitigation measures.In this action health activities will be implemented in 10 out of 14 governorates( exc Idleb,Tartous and Raqqa) and GBV in three(Damscus,RDAM,Daraa)

title.narrative: Strengthen IPC measures in vulnerable communities

description.narrative:
UNICEF will coordinate the WASH response in its capacity as sector lead while strengthening Infection Prevention and Control in health facilities, schools and learning spaces, youth centers and communities. This will be done through the drafting and implementation of IPC protocols, procurement and distribution of IPC supplies, and the promotion of hand washing with soap.
This SHF funded project is embedded within this overall strategy and will focus primarily on three key aspects: Distribution of soap at community level for 3.5 million people (as part of the WFP food distributions), provision of hygiene kits to 13,500 families of children with severe disabilities, and provision of Infection , Prevention and Control supplies to 500 health facilities.

description.narrative: Due to the prolonged crisis in Syria, the public health system is fragile and will require considerable support to reinforce its capacity to support a potential outbreak of COVID-19. Overall, only 57 public hospitals (50 percent2) are fully functioning in the country3 There is also a considerable shortage of trained staff and a high turnover rate, all of which reduce its capacity to manage cases and further puts the health workers on the frontline of response, at risks. Through this project, the PPEs for health care workers and medical equipment for case management of COVID-19 patients to be procured and delivered to MOH and health facilities. This include ultrasound scanners for pregnant patients of COVID-19 and thermometer for entry screening of health facilities.

description.narrative: Nine years of conflict in Syria have created one of the worst humanitarian crises of our time. About 5.6 million Syrians are refugees, and another 6.2 million people are internally displaced. An estimated 12 million people in Syria need humanitarian assistance. At least half of the people affected by the Syria crisis are children. Hundreds of healthcare centers and hospitals, schools and utilities are damaged or destroyed. Families are struggling to survive. Having just endured a harsh winter, they now face the threat of COVID-19, a global pandemic that poses significant risk to vulnerable communities across the world. Altogether, the Syria crisis can feel overwhelming. In fact, it is a “crisis within crisis”. As of April 21, 2020, there have been 42 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the Syrian Arab Republic, including three deaths. Although the number is still low compared to neighboring countries, predictions are it will grow significantly unless immediate and targeted actions are taken by the Government of Syria and humanitarian actors to limit and prevent further spread of COVID-19 in Syria. Half the infections are community transmitted indicating the presence of potentially high number of local coronavirus clusters. Based on the current epidemiological situation in the region, and the capacity of the healthcare system, WHO considers the overall risk for Syria to be very high. Immediate and coordinated actions are needed to prevent a socio-economic and public health catastrophe. In response to the COVID-19 Epidemic and the urgent needs to prevent the spread of the infection in Syria, the project targets the governorates of Daraa, Deir Ezzor and Lattakia with the rehabilitation of Saida Health Center in Daraa Governorate, Al-Hamidiya Health Center in Deir Ezzor City and the Department of the Communicable Diseases in the Lattakia National Hospital. The locations identified in coordination with health sector and the priorities of MoH. The targeted interventions will be implemented through direct contracts with the private sector. The main targeted cities and communities shall serve a population of around 73,000 Including thousands of IDPs scattered across several governorates. The health services in the targeted areas are secured to a minimum and one of the main reasons is the obvious deficit in the number of the functional health facilities which need an immediate intervention to make them functional and ready to facilitate the cooperative efforts made to stop the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic. The level of damage of the targeted health facilities is minor and a light rehabilitation will be enough to cover the need and put the health facilities in service. The rehabilitation works will include civil and architecture works, sanitary works, electrical works, mechanical works, roof waterproofing and the maintenance of the water and sewage networks inside the targeted health facilities limits. The selection criteria of the targeted health facilities are: - The results of pre-assessment report - The selected health facilities are in line with UNDP, WHO and local authorities' priorities - The selected health facilities are in or near a potential outbreak hotspot – population density and vulnerability due to frequent exposure etc., - The selected health facilities are partially damaged and the percentage of damaged doesn't exceed 20%. - The selected health facilities are accessible - The selected health facilities are can be rehabilitated within an execution period of no more than 6 months

title.narrative: Supporting Health facilities and health-workers in Al Hasakeh governorate with preventive measures to enhance their ability during COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative:
In Respond to new emergency needs arising from COVID-19 Pandemic the most affected is the public health system, considering its low capacity to support and respond due to the prolonged crisis in Syria. It requires support to reinforce capacity to face COVID-19. We have limited access to adequate health services In Al Hassakeh as the number of public hospitals that are fully functional is too low in addition to the risk of health workers working on the front-line to response are not fully equipped with prevention means. especially in NES areas that border Syria. The aim of this project is to support preparedness and response actions which support limiting COVID-19 outbreak in Al Hassakeh governorate. It reflects priorities in HRP, supporting medical facilities - Public hospitals - NGOs Clinics and mobile teams especially in camps and overcrowded areas.
In Al Hasakeh Governorate, there are many medical points, Health facilities, that provide great services in light of the prolonged Syrian crisis. These centers provide medical services such as (General health services - surgical operations - medication provision - reproductive health services - vaccination ... etc) These Medical facilities belongs: 1- Non-profit NGOs health facilities 2- Public Health Centers (MOH) All supported mostly by the UN agencies or MOH. they're also spreaded throughout Al Hassakeh governorate (the city of Al Hasakeh and its countryside - Qamishli and its countryside - Al-Qahtaniyah and its countryside - Al Shaddadi - Al-Ya'rubiyah and its countryside - Al Areeshah and al areesha camp- Al Hol and Al Hol camp - Tal Hamis and its countryside - Tal Tamer countryside ...) 1- Al Birr Organization for social services in Qamishli, covers ( Al Hol- Qahtaniyah- Qamishli- Tal Hamis- Al Ya'rubiyah- 2- Al Birr Organization for social services in Al Hassakeh, covers (Al Hassakeh city) 3- Al Mawaddeh, covers (Al Hassakeh countryside) 4- Al Yamama Association, covers (Al Areesha- Al Hol camp- Al Shaddadi) 5- BICA, covers (Al Hassakeh city- Tal Tamer) 6-Al Wasl Charity, covers (Qamishli - Al Ya'rubiyah) 7-Sham Al Kheir Charitable society, covers (Tal Hamis) 8- Qabas Charitable society, covers( Qamishli) 9- Armenian Charity Association, covers(Qamishli) 10- Assyrian Association, covers (Tal Tamer) 11- the National Hospital in Qamishli 12- Al Lo'loaa Medical center in Al Hassakeh city. Total supported teams:15 Health centers 20 Mobile teams After the pandemic was declared a global epidemic by WHO, these centers began to be affected in terms of the quantity and quality of provided services. Not to mention that these centers may raise the spread of COVID-19 if they do not take into account the effective preventive methods. Al-Birr Organization for social services in Qamishli believes that these centers are in urgent need in light of COVID-19 pandemic and need to be provided with the basic preventive means to prevent making these centers one of means for disease outbreak, especially for its importance and need to continue providing services. Al Birr considers the necessity of providing medical centers with sterilizers, masks, and protective suits. For a period of four months, health workers staff will be provided with masks, sterilizers, and protective coveralls. These centers will be provided with preventive means weekly or monthly as available. The masks and sterilizers will be for one time use (for health worker) will be provided continuously for a period of four months. Contracts will be conducted with transportation companies for dispatching items and sraff transportation. Number of beneficiaries the project will serve ( 1098) Health workers .

title.narrative: Providing emergency COVID-19 WASH response actions in formal IDP sites in the city of Hasaka

description.narrative:
ue to the worldwide outbreak and pandemic situation for COVID-19 since Febraury 2020, Syria is not an exception and has, is and will be touched to a certain degree. Even though there are only 38 COVID-19 confirmed cases in Syria (15.04.2020) with only 2 deaths so far, we cannot ignore the fact that COVID-19 virus is present and would continue to spread widely and rapidly, if no preventive actions and measures would be implemented. The Government of Syria has put in place movement restrictions and closing of all non-essential businesses all across the country, and is requesting all citizens to respect physical distancing, limit their movements to the essential activities and implement and reinforce relevant hygiene measures such as handwashing with soup, etc. According to Statistics of Yamamah and the Sub-Relief Committee in Hasaka in the month of April 2020 In North-East Syria (NES), specifically in in Hassakeh Governorate, and IDP-sites exist hosting around 14’250 persons in mostly makeshift accomodations (teAccommodation centers). Persons in these and IDP-sites do not have sufficient living space already, and physical distancing within the accommodation as well as inside t IDP-sites is hardly to completely impossible. Therefore, and based on the reality of having access to limited basic services (WASH, shelter, food, etc.), the risk of potential spreading and potential COVID-19 outbreaks in these areas has to be considered as very high. As health services, not only in IDP-sites, but all over NES area and within Syria are very limited, treatment for COVID-19 patients would be highly challenging and is very limited. Therefore, setting up and running essential COVID-19 prevention actions in general, and particular for WASH, is crucial and indispensable – mainly for IDP-sites, but as well for any other public areas and potentially affected locations, sites, areas and households. Therefore, Syria Al-Yamama has decided to wanting to be highly involved in the COVID-19 response in Syria, and particularily in NES. has working Syria Al Yamama for hygiene promotion, cleaning activities for communal WASH facilities, garbage collection, and water trucking support , IDP sites and other locations Governorate and will continue and expand the WASH activities .In the following shelters
The target centers for hygiene kits distribution, solid waste management, cleaning of public facilities and maintenance of public facilities (Mahmoud Naef, Hamza ben Abed AlMotaleb,Abed AlRahaman Mahboub,Adwa AlHomosh,Thamer AlNouri,Teysser Khaled Abu AlAswad AlDo'ali, Dhahi AlAli,Tishreen ,Assakan AlShababi,Abu Obeida Ben AlJarah,Veillat,AlBa'ath Haroun Alrasheed,Ibed AlAtheer Neff AlZaed,Sofia ,Tweena ) Centers targeted with awareness-raising activities to prevent from COVID 19

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Education in Emergencies in Rural Hama

description.narrative:
The overall objective of the project is to increase equitable access to quality education in safe and protected environment for crisis affected children and youth in Hama district of Syria. The proposed intervention targets 4000 children in five localities (Murak, Kafr Zeata, Karnaz, Braideej and Halfaya) that have recently shifted control. In addition, there has been an influx of IDP´s from Idlib. The influx has increased the needs in the area, which currently has low number of active partners.
The proposed action will provide access to education for 2500 children who have lost, or are at risk of losing access to education through age and grade appropriate catch-up and remedial classes. These classes use MoE approved content, including the accelerated curricula B. The selection of beneficiaries will address specific needs related to gender, disability and seek to integrate children who lack legal documents and identification. A further 1500 in-school children in targeted localities will benefit from school kits, students kits and hygiene kits. The project will indirectly benefit the families and communities with an approximate reach of 20 000 indirect beneficiaries.
The quality of education will be reinforced through this intervention, as the majority of teachers in Syria are not certified. This action will ensure that teachers receive a training before they engage with remedial or catch-up classes. These trainings are based on INEE’s Teachers in Crisis Context (TiCC) training package intended for underqualified teachers in crisis contexts. TiCC includes modules on planning for teaching, teaching strategies, classroom management, special needs of girls and boys in learning environment and inclusive learning. Teachers will also receive trainings in child safeguarding and key child protection related themes such as GBV. A total of 40 teachers will be trained during the course of this project.
Safe, physical school environments will be ensured through the rehabilitation of 62 classrooms in 5 schools. The rehabilitations will ensure that currently overcrowded schools will have an adequate number of safe, equipped classrooms and disability inclusive, gender segregated WASH facilities. The equipment of classrooms and facilities will take into account the specific requirements imposed by COVID-19.
The project builds protective environments by supporting the psychosocial well-being of conflict affected children. Teachers will receive training in understanding the fundaments of Psychosocial Support to enable them to identify symptoms of distress in children. This will enable teachers to refer children who exhibit symptoms of anxiety to specialised services. A referral services and pathway mapping will be conducted together with the school community.
The project will also involve broader communities through creation of school protection committees, to ensure the participation of caregivers. Together with protection committees, interactive and participatory protection events will be organised in each school on key topics - early marriage and gender based violence (GBV), Child labour, ERW and COVID-19.
The risk of the spread of COVID-19 will be mitigated through distribution of hygiene material including soap, sanitizers, gloves and masks. Hand washing posters will be provided and placed in key locations near hand washing facilities. Disinfectant will be provided for classrooms to ensure the environment stays clean. In case of school closures due to COVID-19, teaching will be provided to students using remote methods, Self Learning Program (SLP), WhatsApp and / or radio teaching. All monitoring and evaluation activities will be carried out, taking into account COVID19 guidance and ensuring the safety of beneficiaries.
